notes.title: Legal Notice

notes.text: Successful exploitation of these vulnerabilities could allow an attacker to gain unauthenticated access to system configuration files and execute DLLs with elevated privileges.
notes.title: Risk evaluation

notes.text: CISA recommends users take defensive measures to minimize the risk of exploitation of these vulnerabilities, such as:
notes.title: Recommended Practices

notes.text: Minimize network exposure for all control system devices and/or systems, ensuring they are not accessible from the Internet.
notes.title: Recommended Practices

notes.text: Locate control system networks and remote devices behind firewalls and isolating them from business networks.
notes.title: Recommended Practices

notes.text: When remote access is required, use more secure methods, such as Virtual Private Networks (VPNs), recognizing VPNs may have vulnerabilities and should be updated to the most current version available. Also recognize VPN is only as secure as the connected devices.
notes.title: Recommended Practices

notes.text: CISA reminds organizations to perform proper impact analysis and risk assessment prior to deploying defensive measures.
notes.title: Recommended Practices

notes.text: CISA also provides a section for control systems security recommended practices on the ICS webpage on cisa.gov/ics. Several CISA products detailing cyber defense best practices are available for reading and download, including Improving Industrial Control Systems Cybersecurity with Defense-in-Depth Strategies.
notes.title: Recommended Practices

notes.text: CISA encourages organizations to implement recommended cybersecurity strategies for proactive defense of ICS assets.
notes.title: Recommended Practices

notes.text: Additional mitigation guidance and recommended practices are publicly available on the ICS webpage at cisa.gov/ics in the technical information paper, ICS-TIP-12-146-01B--Targeted Cyber Intrusion Detection and Mitigation Strategies.
notes.title: Recommended Practices

notes.text: Organizations observing suspected malicious activity should follow established internal procedures and report findings to CISA for tracking and correlation against other incidents.
notes.title: Recommended Practices

notes.text: No known public exploitation specifically targeting these vulnerabilities has been reported to CISA at this time. These vulnerabilities were not exploitable remotely.
notes.title: Recommended Practices

document.title: Rockwell Automation FactoryTalk View Site Edition

product.name: Rockwell Automation FactoryTalk View Site Edition: <15.0

cwe.name: Incorrect Permission Assignment for Critical Resource

notes.text: An incorrect permission assignment vulnerability exists in Rockwell Automation FactoryTalk View Site Edition products on all versions prior to Version 15.0. The vulnerability is due to incorrect permissions being assigned to the remote debugger port and can allow for unauthenticated access to the system configuration.
notes.title: Vulnerability Summary

remediations.details: Rockwell Automation encourages users of the affected software to apply the following risk mitigations, if possible:
For CVE-2025-24481: *-* Upgrade to V15.0 or apply patch. Answer ID 1152306 *-* Protect physical access to the workstation *-* Restrict access to Port 8091 at the network or workstation
Upgrade to V15.0 or apply patch. Answer ID 1152306
Protect physical access to the workstation
Restrict access to Port 8091 at the network or workstation
Upgrade to V15.0 or apply patch. Answer ID 1152304.
Check the environment variables (PATH), and make sure FactoryTalk® View SE installation path (C:\Program Files (x86)\Common Files\Rockwell) is before all others

For information on how to mitigate Security Risks on industrial automation control systems, Rockwell Automation asks users to implement their suggested security best practices to minimize the risk of the vulnerabilities.
Users can use Stakeholder-Specific Vulnerability Categorization to generate more environment-specific prioritization.

cwe.name: Improper Control of Generation of Code ('Code Injection')

notes.text: A local code injection vulnerability exists in Rockwell Automation FactoryTalk View Site Edition products on all versions prior to Version 15.0. The vulnerability is due to incorrect default permissions and allows for DLLs to be executed with higher level permissions.
